positive.review:
EVE Online is probably the deepest and most complex game you'll ever play. Very broadly speaking you might enjoy this game if you enjoy any of the following genres:

[list]
[*]Economy/business/trade games (X4, Offworld Trading Company, Runescape)
[*]Factory/logistics games (Factorio, Transport Fever, Anno)
[*]Truck/cargo simulators (Euro Truck Simulator, Star Trucker)
[*]Space combat/piracy (Elite: Dangerous, Star Citizen)
[*]Space mining (Elite: Dangerous)
[*]Empire building/politics (Stellaris, sort of)
[*]Dystopian space capitalism in general
[/list]

Yes, the game really is this broad. And while it may be a clich√© at this point, the only way to really know if EVE is your kind of game is to try it yourself. So if you‚Äôre willing to dive on in, let me provide you with some information to make sure you have the best experience.

[h3]Unlimited Free Trial[/h3]
EVE Online is free-to-play for as much as you want, and will let you try out more than enough activities to see what takes your fancy. The entire map is accessible to you, as well as a very generous selection of spaceships. Take your time, EVE is best enjoyed as a marathon, rather than a sprint.

[h3]Do the Tutorial. No really.[/h3]
EVE has earned its reputation as one of the hardest games to get to grips with, and there are many different game mechanics to learn. The tutorial will help you understand the core mechanics of the game and gives you some money and new ships along the way. After the introductory tutorial you‚Äôll be given the chance to work for several career agents who‚Äôs missions will teach you more about specific activities in the game. Do them all. It will give you some starter capital and valuable information. As the final exam, consider doing The Blood-Stained Stars Epic Arc to wrap up your introduction to New Eden.

[h3]Ask For Help[/h3]
Did I mention EVE is bloody complicated? You [i]will[/i] have questions. As a new players you will automatically join the Rookie Help channel where you can ask anything you want and get (mostly) useful answers. EVE has a very newbie friendly community, we want to see you succeed, and will do anything in our power to help you out.

[h3]Join a Corporation[/h3]
EVE is, at its core, a social game. Everything you do interacts with other players in one way or another. Corporations are EVE‚Äôs guilds or clans, and joining one is a great way to find friends to fly with. Personally I would recommend all new players join up with EVE University. They are the oldest and best accredited new player corporation in the game and also maintain the game‚Äôs unofficial wiki. It is a good place to learn the game and ask questions.

[h3]Hit me up![/h3]
If this review has been helpful to you and you‚Äôre looking for more help to find your way, feel free to contact me either on Steam or in-game. I‚Äôm always happy to help eager newbies find their way in this amazingly unique game.

Fly safe!

Eve online is a fascinating experience. The best way I can describe it is it's kind of like a microcosm of the modern internet experience even though it's ostensibly a game. You deal with the best and worst of it. 

You can forge some real friendships or you could just be a lurker quietly doing their own thing as everything burns in the distance. 
Sometimes those friends stab you in the back.
Every once in a while, something big happens that might capture your attention and then you'll go back to doing your own thing. 
There's a market and you can sometimes make some money with it but chances are most of it run by large corporations full of wealth beyond your comprehension that makes more money per second than some people have made their entire lives.
Outside of the market, the jobs people ask you to do generally pay shit for the amount of work, time and risk you're expected to do. 
Sometimes you find a neat little thing that captures your attention and you do that for a bit until you go do the next thing.
There's sometimes scammers and they make fake websites to trick you into giving them money. 
There's sometimes people who try to steal your profile info and sell that for money. 
There's sometimes huge things that look really big and sound exciting to use but nobody actually cares about it anymore and cost an exorbitant amount of resources to make. 
Sometimes people are causing massive destructive sequences that burns through an insane amount of other stuff that people made. 
Sometimes people name themselves and their stuff using anime references. 
There's large organizations that everyone is born into that own massive amounts of territory and seem very large and scary but in reality don't do very much except start conflict between themselves that the regular person rarely finds themselves involved with unless they get actively involved. 
The game has a player run council full of people that I didn't vote for talking about things that are mostly completely detached to me just trying to do my own thing unless you care about it then you have extremely strong opinions about it. 
Sometimes the inside of the place you're visiting gets hacked and gets digitally defaced. 
And sometimes the memes people share are actually funny.

All I can say is there are very few games that are like this one and I'm never sure if I actually enjoy being here but I'm still playing it anyways.
Honestly, it's one of the best games that has ever been made.  Insanely complex, and insanely rewarding.

The learning curve is massive, but worth the grind. Not really sure why people complain about the "community" as the community is up to you to decide. It is very easy to find a group (Corp) to play with like minded people. Not to mention many if not most have some sort of new recruit learn the ropes kind of thing. Give it a shot and leave the cesspool of Jita local.

You'll either have the best time of your life, or the worst time of your life. Or both, probably. First one, then the other. Then repeat. 

It's the single game I have most consistently played for over 15 years. You'll get out of it what you put into it.

I have been playing EVE since 2007 and took a few breaks along the way. Here is my fair and honest review in a chronological order.

As I said, I started in 2007 with some IRL friends, we all moved further apart because of work and this game was such a great way for us to connect and have fun online. We were super noobs and didn't know what to do so we created our own Corp and learned by making very expensive mistakes but we got better and it got way more fun once we joined an alliance and moved into Null Sec (0.0 security player owned space).  Unfortunately some of these friends of mine stopped playing and I continued playing with people I met online. It was still great and I learned so much more from them but already I felt like it wasn't as fun anymore.
TLDR: It's very fun playing this game among friends

I stopped playing around 2009 but came back in 2011 after reading a news article about a big shake up in Null Sec. Only 1/4 of the players I had met online were still playing together, the rest were still active but scattered to other Corp/Alliance. There had been some backstabbing, theft and paranoia had increased significantly. I had to go through an interview and provide my API to prove that I wasn't a spy. The game had changed so much more than I thought at first. I like that the game allows such player betrayal and interaction but it's the players themselves, the greed got too far and killed the fun of this game, it was no longer a game, it was for many players, their whole life's focus. The paranoia had led to some players running 12+ accounts and soloing their own corporation due to not being able to trust anyone
TLDR: Very paranoid community due to in-game mechanics that allow theft and betrayal.

I continued playing from 2011 to 2014 but much more casually than during my first experience in 2007-2009 with IRL friends.

After quitting in 2014, I did a few brief comebacks in 2018, 2022 and now in 2025.  The average EVE Player owns 3 or 4 accounts so keep that in mind when you see something around 35,000 online. Many players own more than 10 accounts.

The new Alpha clone is a good idea to bring new players into the game, it lets you reach 5 mil SP. If you're brand new and want to give it a try, The social aspect is still the most important part of this game, regardless of the paranoia.  In the end, even though the game has lost it's fun for me, I still think it's an incredible game, don't play it solo, you will get so bored. Join a Player Corp, get on Voice and get ready for a steep learning curve but if you're into Sci-Fi and space ships, you'll definitely enjoy it.

Eve is a 'play to win' game, but you can also make a lot of space money through piracy and other behaviors you probably won't talk about IRL. If that sounds fun and you have a couple 1000 hours a year and some spare cash, Eve is for you.

This will be honest review of an Alpha player.
 
I've tried getting into the game 2-3 times thru out the years and always liked it, but my friends always dragged me to something else. Playing MMOs for more than 20 years.

However, I've been playing EVE (Everything vs Everything) actively the last month and having a blast.

*I'm an Alpha - I have access to so many stuff that I still don't see the need of Omega anytime soon.
*I'm explorer - I fly Heron (small and fast ship), exploring and hacking sites without any gunnery.
*I've met people everywhere doing everything. 
*There are schemes, tactics, backstabbing, politics, invasions, wars, crime, gambling and so on...


The space is vast, systems have different Suns and Moons, pirates are waiting in an ambush.
It's a hardcore game and I love it.
When they destroy your ship - it's gone for good. 

There are many ships. MANY!
Very different from each other with complementary of its own playstyle, like:

Sharpshooter - long range rocket launcher 
Brawler - close combat with high speed turrets
DJ - you can use all the different colored lasers
Bomber - create a labyrinths of mines and bombs
Tackler - hold them in place with nets, prevent them from warping
Vampire - drink their power, leave them useless
Medic - provide support by giving shield to frontlines 

and many more. THOSE roles are made up by me, not actual in game terms.

Economy is player driven, tons of helping people, tons of content for new bros.
Everything YOU buy is either crafted or gathered by another player. Each ship you fly, someone made it in their hangar. 
Everything YOU find can be sold, salvaged, used in some way. 

And this is from a guy with less than month flying around my yellow duck Heron, playing few hours a day.

o7   Good luck and fly safe, but remember - YOU ARE NEVER ALONE IN EVE!   o7

Eve online is one of the most engaging MMOs I've played since the late 2000s. This game has come so far in so many years. The game looks fantastic and continues to develop its engine to keep it modernized and the so many people are long time players who continue to play this player driven game. This game has the most sophisticated ecosystem and economy to date. No other game truly even comes close to the complexity of everything being made by a player. From basic ore refining to massive dreadnaughts. Everything is made by a player. 

The complexities of this game at a social level are insane. Massive corporations forming, claiming and protecting their own areas of space. Have massive wars against each other or form up together to make massive alliances all of which have their own internal politics and laws/rules. 

If you are looking for a proper space pvp/pve game fully driven by it‚Äôs player made economy this is it. No other game even comes close to this.

I first started in EvE in 2005, then took breaks and stopped altogether in 2015

I have now returned to New Eden 10 years later... and the changes are immense, yet still simple enough for NEW players to grasp.  

The majority of negativity from players is that the game essentially requires a monthly subscription, yet I find it more of a blessing.  I've played plenty of MMOs where the free to play or less expensive subscription options allow more of the immature players in, so the subscription acts as a gatekeeper so to speak.

Yes, PvP is real and can occur in ANY part of the Universe but it is so rare in HiSec (High Security space) that players really don't benefit due to the increased penalties assessed... until they and their ships are destroyed as well.  The biggest complainers are the people who let emotion get the best of them, so don't react like a child... rather plan and conquer your part of the universe like an adult instead.

CCP also provides all sorts of opportunity for you to see if the game is relevant for your tastes with its Alpha option prior to subscribing with the Omega option.  Not only that, but they also offer discounts and promotions all the time.

If you are interested in checking it out, you don't have really anything to lose as you can play for quite some time without spending any RL money.  ALSO, if you are smart enough, you can actually make enough in game ISK to pay for your subscription WITHOUT spending RL money ;)

If you decide to check it out as a New or Returning player, feel free to say hello and ask me about the extra 1 Million Skill Points you can get (even for FREE accounts)

EVE Online is one of the most unique MMORPGs ever created, and Goonswarm Federation stands out as one of its most influential alliances, offering players a thrilling mix of strategy, camaraderie, and large-scale space warfare.

üåå EVE Online: A Universe Like No Other
- Sandbox Freedom: Unlike most MMOs, EVE Online doesn‚Äôt lock you into a single path. You can be a miner, trader, pirate, mercenary, or fleet commander. The game‚Äôs sandbox design means your choices genuinely shape the galaxy.
- Epic Scale: With over 7,200 star systems to explore, battles can involve thousands of players at once. These wars are not scripted events but player-driven conflicts that make headlines in the gaming world.
- Community & Social Depth: Success in EVE isn‚Äôt just about grinding levels‚Äîit‚Äôs about building alliances, trust, and strategy. Many players highlight the long-term engagement and social bonds as the most rewarding aspects.
- Positive Reception: On Steam, EVE Online holds a ‚ÄúMostly Positive‚Äù rating from tens of thousands of reviews, with players praising its depth and uniqueness. Critics often call it the best true sandbox MMO ever made.

üõ°Ô∏è Goonswarm Federation: Legends of Nullsec
- Massive Influence: Goonswarm is one of the largest and most iconic alliances in EVE Online, known for shaping the political and military landscape of New Eden.
- Welcoming to New Players: Many newcomers report that joining Goonswarm provides structure, mentorship, and access to resources that make the steep learning curve of EVE much more manageable.
- Rich History: From legendary wars to strategic relocations (such as their move from Delve to Tenerifis), Goonswarm has consistently demonstrated tactical mastery and resilience.
- Community Spirit: Players often describe Goonswarm as a place where you can find camaraderie, humor, and shared purpose. Being part of BROTY (a Goonswarm corporation) is seen as a gateway to experiencing the best of EVE‚Äôs alliance life.

‚≠ê Final Thoughts
EVE Online rewards patience and ambition with one of the richest gaming experiences available. Goonswarm Federation exemplifies the best of what the game has to offer: epic battles, strong community bonds, and a lasting impact on the galaxy‚Äôs history. Together, they create a gaming experience that is both challenging and unforgettable.

Do you remember playing with construction blocks with other kids? When you spent a lot of time with a friend building a big castle? When the other kid smashed your tower? When you anticipated the inevitable collapse while you tried to balance every single block?

Eve is like that, but with spaceships. It stirs a lot of emotions inside you. It's a lot of fun, and more when you find a good corp.

Do not be tricked : resource gathering activities are not the goal. They are a means to build your kingdom. Everyone could be building an ever bigger kingdom together, a glorious space odyssey. But someone comes and topples what you built : the kingdom shatters, splinters into factions.

Of course everyone knows, deep inside, that it would end up this way. Scarcity coupled with boredom will do that to you. You'll eventually come to peace with the struggle, and come to appreciate what makes this game truly unique : watching things crumble together, cheer on the good fight, and build again with a vengence.

The vast majority of people in Eve want everybody to have a good time, and will care about you even though they just blew up your ship. You just need to learn into making that more... consensual? Idk the game does have the tendency to stimulate your inner psychopath, you just need to kinda lean on that.

Finally Eve is pretty upfront about the business model : you try for free, and you pay for full content. Don't make the game into your second job. You can put in money for in game currency: be responsible, make a concious choice and don't fly what you are not willing to lose.

All in all, 9/10 would kill a keepstar with 1500 other people again.

Hugely deep and interesting gameplay. It does take some effort to break through the initial complexity but its worth it. Once you break through (which doesn't take too long) the depth and opportunity are unmatched.

negative.review:
Gave it a good college try. Spent over 150+ hours playing. Doing my best to learn. Taking things slow but by god this game is horrible for new players and even worse for new players trying to get into more advanced parts of the game. There is no good website or wiki that can give you straight answers to any questions you might have and any that they do are a roll of the dice as there has been so many changes that they may not apply anymore. You have to hope that years ago someone on reddit asked the same thing and got a usable answer.

All of this would be fine to deal with as you could take it easy and just learn as you go. Sadly the community is filled with people who have decided that they want to make your experience with the game much worse. Looking to build, mine, or explore anything slightly past the beginner stuff will put you in the firing line of pirate players and PVP. Even if you want nothing to do with that experience it is thrust upon you by their whims. Putting back hours of work and serenity for a moment of being stuck in place until they finish gunning you down. Followed by them shooting your escape pod for kicks and giggles. These basement dwelling bastards just make things worse.

Before anyone starts pointing out the many ways to avoid or escape from these wastes of space pirates. I no longer care. If the only way to learn these sorts of things is to have them pointed out in the comments of a negative review, then it is bad design and an even worse community. One I won't be part of anymore.

TL;DR - Kind of a mixed bag.

It's not a terrible game but the devs are constantly trying to force combat PVP onto players that want no part of it. Most game mechanics are geared toward this and it gets very tiresome very fast. It's like it's their only goal and any expansions or new features almost completely ignore players that aren't mouth-frothing psychopaths.

The latest Catalyst expansion is a good example. Sure it added some stuff and made some changes to mining that were sorely needed across the entire game but the really interesting stuff is locked behind PVP (as always). The mining changes that didn't involve trying to force PVP on everyone only highlighted the fact that asteroids are FAR TOO SMALL for serious miners. "Let's make mining better but give them nothing to mine! HAHA NERDS!" - CCP
It's like you can't facepalm hard enough...

I've met some really awesome people in the game and made good friends over the years, but I've also witnessed the worst of humanity in it as well. Seriously, if some of these people aren't on government watch lists or literally playing from supermax prison I'd be very surprised. 

Something is very broken in the human genome (clearly) and this game attracts it like fat kids to cupcakes. I guess my biggest problem with it is that the devs actively support and encourage it. It's kind of sad to see such wasted potential.

I have absolutely no idea why this game still exists or why anyone is still playing it. It‚Äôs one of the biggest scams ever created. ‚ÄúFREE‚Äù? Yeah, free to install. That‚Äôs it. The rest is a bottomless pit.

I won‚Äôt even start with the industry behind this thing ‚Äî the money people dump into ‚ÄúChina farming‚Äù or PLEX is unbelievable. How can people be this blind and this dumb? Every so-called ‚Äúpatch‚Äù or ‚Äúevent‚Äù gets hyped like it‚Äôs revolutionary, yet nothing ever changes. It‚Äôs the same old mess, repackaged again and again.

I deleted it from my Steam library. I tried every possible option to hide, block, or get rid of it. But no ‚Äî this relic keeps crawling back into visibility like a bad infection.

CCP, for the sake of humanity, shut down your servers. The game could have been great, but with its broken mechanics and the absurd need to buy Omega, it has become one of the worst scams in gaming. Seriously. Wake up.

I can‚Äôt even say what I really think about the game and CCP, because it wouldn‚Äôt fit any rules or guidelines, not even remotely. So I‚Äôll leave it at this: end the misery, free the poor souls trapped in that universe, and for anyone thinking about ‚Äútrying it because it‚Äôs free‚Äù ‚Äî please don‚Äôt. EVE is more interesting to read about than to actually play.
Power bloc clashes and battles involving thousands of pilots sound epic. I came to the game for the beautiful ships and space scenery, expecting an incredible adventure. But all the magic fades away right after completing the tutorial missions.

For decades, EVE has suffered from long-standing issues that seriously affect the player base. The support is unfriendly, and there‚Äôs no meaningful mid-game content. The core game design combines two incompatible things: grind and roaming. Whether you want PvE or PvP, you often have to roam endlessly. In the end, you spend far more hours searching and waiting than actually playing. The loot is inconsistent, and it‚Äôs easy to waste several hours grinding for a trivial reward.

The game gives massive PvP advantages to older accounts. Veterans know a thousand ways to destroy a new player. Newcomers in weak ships are killed ‚Äúfor fun‚Äù by pilots flying T2 or T3 ships through multiple accounts. They brag about their kill counts. It quickly becomes clear that new players are just prey ‚Äî farmed by veterans. At that point, you realize what the developers‚Äô design truly is, and it‚Äôs easy to decide your time deserves a better experience elsewhere.

The dev team completely lacks the courage to evolve the game. Everything is built around keeping EVE frozen in its broken state while a small core of loyal players keeps paying. Even multiboxing has been integrated into the monetization system.

Imagine looking for fair, exciting PvP ‚Äî and your opponent simply switches to a second window with a stronger ship to finish you off once his first one tackles you. Where‚Äôs the fun in that? Gang-style PvP offers no thrill ‚Äî only wasted time and a lost ship.

Large-scale battles with thousands of pilots cause massive time dilation. Ships pile up, and the server runs at the speed of 2 FPS per minute ‚Äî pure disappointment.

CCP keeps developing new games instead of fixing EVE. Yet all it would take to revive EVE is the courage to address its core problems.

Pretty deep and complex game managed and developed by one of the greediest and incompetent game development companies on earth.

Beyond the very basics, this game requires multiple accounts that all need to be subscribed in order to be competitive.

It's one of the most pay to win games in existence. Buying real money currency from them can be used to buy better ships, skill points, etc. The more money you spend, the more powerful you get. Sky is the limit, really.

Content is designed to cater to those who fly multiple accounts only. Most of the game is really designed around PVP, PVE content is ocean-wide but puddle-deep. There's next to no complexity in PVE, and PVE is only there to finance PVP. Most of the high-end PVE content is extremely restricted as it requires significant time investment and membership in the groups that would allow you to take advantage of it, which are limited at best. Yes, you read that right, in order to participate in some of the content in this game, you have to be a member of groups that control access to that content. If you're not one of them, enjoy the scraps you get in "high-security space."

This game's general approach to player experience is "if game mechanics allow it, it's fair game." On its surface it's a good proposition, but when you get down to it, this is a game run by griefers, gankers and scammers. You can get lied to and stolen from, scammed using anything from your naivete, to poorly designed ui and game mechanics, and the dev will do NOTHING. You're on your own.

This is a PvP space simulator, not a game. To do anything you'll need to do your own research about everything involved in such activity before another player or something that you didn't read about comes and kills you, which means you loose your ship and everything in it. And there is a lot to do, which means you'll have to learn it all before trying it. If you want a frustrating part time job that costs you money, Eve is it. Duck this simulator

If you're a sociopath with a flair for sato masochism then this is your game!  I have been playing EVE off an on for over two decades now.  Recently I have retired from playing because the devs just want ships to go boom.  The bottom line of this game and the underlying economy within rely on ships being blow up and replaced.  This is all well and good if you are in a mega corp in a corp controlled area of space where resources are mined and processed.  But if you have played EVE long enough you know that you can trust no one because every other player is looking for a come up however they can.  So after learning this and trying to play solo for the last few years i find the game broken and bent to the will of all of the large corporations.

Favoring large corps over the individual is a byproduct of CCP's business model. This happens because the devs want to keep the large corps happy because they represent the largest portion of the player base.  There is no room in this game anymore for the individual, only giant corps.  If people need in game currency to replace their ship that was just blown up they can buy it rather than grind the game to earn ISK.  I have seen a constant push from CCP to limit what the individual can procure by themselves for a more corporation centered play style.  This leaves casual players out in the cold.  These days you cant even mine in Hi-Sec because fleets are so starved for anything fun to do that they attack mining and shipping vessles as a crutch for engaging, intriguing battles where others fight back.  The devs have facilitated this by making conditions more favorable to attackers rather than defenders even in Hi sec space.  At the end of the day they have made it more expensive to replace ships and modules (artificial scarcity) and limited the amount a miner or ship/module builder can make (market manipulation).  Thus the miner or builder must buy ISK as a replacement for actual in game earnings because his means to ends is destroyed either by other players (actual ship destruction) or his goods are vastly deflated in value (economic manipulation caused by CCP pulling strings, usually in the form of updates).

Pretty much all updates over the past 15 years have been newly introduced content centered around building higher tier items which command the highest prices on the market.  The issue?  Only large corporations are able to control the areas of space where these items can be found.  Thus handing even more power to these already elitist entities.  

Beyond that, things that solo players are able to do are a waste of time now.  The systems that were set up for initial players and solo players were added to the game so long ago that the rewards for doing these tasks/missions no longer match the risk to reward ratio.

Want to run a mission for 90,000 ISK? Sure, all you will need is a 3,750,000 ISK ship to do it in!
   
Solo Mining low level asteroids?  CCP nerfed the amount and concentration of minerals you are able to harvest in secure space.  CCP has also encouraged fleets to kill mining vessels in hi sec with no reperocussions (other than a T1 destroyer, destroyed and replaced by a SRP out of a corp hanger).  In my opinion if a character has killed in hi sec and their victim was not a legitimate war/faction target then security forces should kill on site in hi sec for the rest of time.  This would curtail the curb stomping of Bambis who are just learning the game.    

Building modules?  CCP altered the distribution of higher tier constituent ingredients to space that is only accessible by, you guessed it, large corporations.  CCP locked reactions (Ingredients for T2 and T3 technologies) to low/null security space.  Making it so a solo player cannot create anything of actual value like T2/T3  ships or modules without buying astronomically priced ingredients and losing all profit margins to, you guessed it again, large corporations.

Flying solo missions, Fetch, fight?  The missions have been around since basically the inception of EVE online.  I'm probably wrong but from what I have seen the developers of the game have never re-balanced rewards from solo missions.  The rewards you are able to get from grinding lvl 3 and 4 combat missions is abysmal.  The market has had issues, like a real economy does, which has led to inflation if ISK throughout New Eden over the years.  The rewards from mission givers and bounties from NPC rats has not kept up with inflationary trends by any means.  This is a deep topic as the missions were put into the game before the newer high end modules and ships.  I could speak on this more but for brevity's sake just know missions have not been updated in over a decade unless you are talking mission in low sec and null space, again handing more ISK and power to Corps.

I give this game a 5/10 in its current state.  Awesome concept but has become somewhat of a trainwreck for new players IMHO.  I feel like the downfall of EVE is that they only cater to Corps and have left the individual behind.  Couple that with the fact that the price for OMEGA has doubled in the last 10 years for no additional content and there's really no place for me in the game anymore. 

-Some Rando w/ 73,000,000 SP

[h1] Not the Sandbox You‚Äôre Promised [/h1]

EVE Online looks incredible and sounds deep, but it‚Äôs not the open-ended universe the trailers suggest.

You won‚Äôt forge your destiny, you‚Äôll instead maintain someone else‚Äôs empire.

The economy is run by entrenched alliances operating like corporations. Miners, haulers, and industrialists grind to feed those machines, not to build for themselves. Exploration is mostly risk management.

Faction Warfare is the closest thing left to purpose: small-scale empire combat where you can actually see territory change. But even that serves a static narrative as the empires never win or lose, the war just resets to keep you occupied.

Veteran ‚Äúwhales‚Äù fund and dominate the system, and CCP designs around them. The lore barely advances, and new players fill the labor gap that keeps the game world spinning.

If you want to study a living experiment in digital feudalism, EVE is fascinating.
If you want a game where your time or choices matter, look elsewhere.

Play it for the spectacle, not the dream.

New player experience... playing for ~2 weeks. Imagine an RTS where you control one(1) unit and your controls are a small bar of symbols that can be exited and lost in the UI. And they don't even work all the time due to pathing issues. The UI is awash in monetization, engagement, and progression mechanics. The worldbuilding is baked into the aesthetic and writing -- so much that it becomes unintuitive. From the game jargon, the acronyms, the endless windows and boxy forgettable symbols, it feels like a cyberpunk DMV just getting through the spaceport.

However the main issue is, like I said, the controls. The most actiony part of the game is the least intuitive. When you warp into a cloud of enemies you cannot simply press back or turn to get to a better position. You move by clicking things to orient yourself towards, and click to move toward or away from them. There is an untargeted way to move, but it's buggy and the ship will often wander in circles, presumably because of bad pathing. You'll also get hung up on invisible walls, stuck pathing through a huge obstacle, or just disappear right through it because no collision.

In most games with real time combat you have simple movement controls, and then from that foundation you build other things like, targeting, interaction, firing, countermeasures, anything you need to do in a split second. That's absent here. Things that should be simple are bizarrely obscure.

Because of this it takes a while to get past the 'learning' and into the gameplay loop, which is basically a spaceship-centered RPG... with some extraction shooter edge. That could be fun, but it looks like most of the ships (including all the higher tier ones) require premium time to use. As if buying these ships after hundreds of hours to earn them, means they are held hostage if I don't pay real money to use them. This suggests a strong p2w model centered on whales. Apparently this game arose around the same time as WoW, and I have nothing against live service/freemium games, but people that make a living off of predatory marketing aren't likely to switch to another model. Similar to WoW, it's probably mostly fun with friends. I can't recommend it until they figure out how to simplify the UI in general and especially combat movement. The ships and the setting do look nice, for what it's worth.

Edit: As expected, pvp combat is janky, there's no counterplay if you haven't spent more time and money, the emphasis is on stacking odds and punishing the weak for being weak. The game mechanics that allow and reward griefing have to be intentional after 22 years in.
Still only a game that is good to play if you are part of a large fleet.  If you are a solo player it still has a community that quickly punishes you for daring to play by yourself.

Let me start out by saying this game isn't for me.  I can definitely see how someone who loves economics, space, and a solid challenge might love this game, so take my review with a grain of salt.

This game has a huge learning curve.  The combat is not involved enough for my tastes, and the world is almost too sandbox.  I prefer MMO's with a little more direction - I know some people love the concept of doing essentially whatever you want in an MMO, but it's not for me. The combat is not my style - I like things that require more input from the player.  Also, I wish that there was more player communication outside of corporations - local channels tend to be dead, and global channels are very topically limited.  Doing missions is impossible as a pair (okay, you can, but only one person gets credit at a time). This makes Eve more of a single player game in the beginning, and makes it less attractive to play with friends than other MMO's might be.

Tl;Dr:

- stale combat
- not enough direction for an MMO
- lack of overall community /early fleet gameplay for new players

Honestly, the community ruins this game completely.
EVE might have depth and cool ships, but none of that matters when every interaction feels toxic.

New players get mocked, scammed, or blown up for fun. Ask a question? You get sarcasm. Try to learn? Someone ganks you just because they can.

People say EVE has a ‚Äúhardcore‚Äù player base ‚Äî nah, it‚Äôs just hostile and arrogant. Even League of Legends feels friendly compared to this mess.

Doesn‚Äôt matter how good the game is if the people in it make you regret logging in.

Multiboxing effectively destroyed the game, and is the root of most of the games problems, particularly the griefing. CCP should have nipped it in the bud over a decade ago, now it's so far gone they can't stop multiboxing without killing the game. That fleet of 12 Catalysts that ganked your Exhumer? That's not 12 pilots, it's one guy input broadcasting to 12 accounts. 

His entire fleet might be 100 mil. Your hull alone is three times more expensive than his entire fleet, that's before we even touch fittings. Meanwhile, you can roam nullsec for hours without seeing a soul. Why? Because griefers aren't PVPers, and people in Null fight back.

All the group content in this game? Multibox solo, absolutely no point in having a community. You can more easily do it yourself, than actually play the MMO like an MMO. How you might ask? Well it's easy, just open up your wallet. You can buy skill injectors, PLEX, sell it for ISK. You can have a fleet as big as you want as quickly as you desire, all you've gotta do is open your wallet wider. Isk and skillpoints are the only thing in this game that really matter, and you can buy both.

Play EVE? No, go to work instead, a 9 to 5 then come home and just buy your way to whatever you want to do. EVE Isn't a game, it's a multiboxing, P2W waste of time. The ONLY thing left here of any note is Nullsec PVP, and a bit of FW. That's it. If you plan to just live in high sec there's a 90% chance you'll quit this game within a month. I've put hours into EVE, I started my first toon back in 2007.

The game spat in my face repeatedly, the devs chose greed over gameplay. Today, I simply do not have the time to give to this game anymore, so I've quit. I've engaged in effectively every gameplay loop EVE has to offer, PVE and PVP. I've basically done it all. I've mined, fought, explored in null, low, high, WH. I've roamed, I've griefed, been griefed, pirated and been pirated, bubbled people and been caught in bubbles, missions, relics and data sites, solo roaming, small fleets, blobs, rats, daytrading, industry, PI. 

The game isn't worth your time unless you want PVP and even then, you'll either multibox, or you'll lose.

Even back in the old days, and i mean really old, Trinity old, the subscription model was a hard sell for the pace of the game. Doesnt matter how much you play, you can only advance as fast as the training allows.

Now nearly 20 years later the only thing that has changed is that subscription has gotten more expensive. Sure you play the filler cannon fodder role for free now but thats about all you can do. No industry, no mining, no economics. No specialized roles such as stealth bombing or electronic warfare. Just an ordinary ship of the line to fill space in a fleet. Though even then you wont be the "best" ordinary ship as level 5 is blocked lol.

The concept of EVE is incredible, its one of the only games left to have a world that is run more by players than the game itself. with a real economy and real consequences to actions.

However 20 dollars a month for a game that caps your progression speed is hilarious, especially when it is still essentially a spread sheet simulator with an amazing pretty screen saver running in the background as its always been.

If they removed omega (subscription) requirements from combat roles (as economic and progression ease should be enough of an incentive) id recommend it, but unless you plan to pay the sub you cant do anything serious even in a large corp other than just being an ordinary semi ok ship of the line lol.

You'll look nice after half a year wait of skill training in that shiny battleship loaded with missiles, youll be proud and ready to engage the enemy with your corp fleet.  But you'll also just be an extra in a movie to blow up and die because the level 5 of the skill which impacts missile range is locked behind a sub, meaning no matter what anyone who is paying that $20 will be better than you because they will out range you, and there is nothing you can do about it.

It's not pay to win
but it is free to die

If you're new to EVE, prepare to be farmed by veterans. The game heavily favors older players with deep wallets and multibox fleets. PvE content is nearly nonexistent unless you're willing to risk being ganked constantly. Once your ship value crosses 250k, you're basically a flashing target.
Multiboxing dominates every corner of space, making solo or casual play feel pointless. The economy is bloated, the learning curve is brutal, and the UI feels like it was designed in 2003 and never updated. Even basic tasks require third-party tools or spreadsheets.
Sure, some people enjoy this hardcore sandbox style. If you're one of them, more power to you. But for me, I'm just another name added to the pile of players who gave it a shot and bounced.

Gave it a good college try. Spent over 150+ hours playing. Doing my best to learn. Taking things slow but by god this game is horrible for new players and even worse for new players trying to get into more advanced parts of the game. There is no good website or wiki that can give you straight answers to any questions you might have and any that they do are a roll of the dice as there has been so many changes that they may not apply anymore. You have to hope that years ago someone on reddit asked the same thing and got a usable answer.

All of this would be fine to deal with as you could take it easy and just learn as you go. Sadly the community is filled with people who have decided that they want to make your experience with the game much worse. Looking to build, mine, or explore anything slightly past the beginner stuff will put you in the firing line of pirate players and PVP. Even if you want nothing to do with that experience it is thrust upon you by their whims. Putting back hours of work and serenity for a moment of being stuck in place until they finish gunning you down. Followed by them shooting your escape pod for kicks and giggles. These basement dwelling bastards just make things worse.

Before anyone starts pointing out the many ways to avoid or escape from these wastes of space pirates. I no longer care. If the only way to learn these sorts of things is to have them pointed out in the comments of a negative review, then it is bad design and an even worse community. One I won't be part of anymore.

EVE Online is less a video game and more an intergalactic corporate job where your soul gets audited daily, and while that‚Äôs kind of impressive in scale, it‚Äôs also about as fun as actually working in corporate without getting paid for it and rather you having to pay for the work or at least if don't have an eternity of spare time. The universe is massive, player driven, and rich with history, but unless you‚Äôre willing to spend months learning acronyms and mechanics, you‚Äôll be stuck as cannon fodder in a space war you don‚Äôt understand. The community stories are legendary, the heists, betrayals, massive space battles, but most of those are things you read about on gaming news sites you find whilst researching about what yet another thing is rather than experience yourself. In the end, it is fascinating to observe from the outside, like a digital anthropology project, but actually sitting down to play it often feels more like a club where the doors are locked to newcomers, and the only ones left inside are veterans playing politics.

I have been playing this game before many here were even born. First time I played Eve was in 2001 I think? Anyway, it captivated me a lot with its openness and truly what felt like endless space with endless possibilities, I fell in love with this game, back then the giants like BoB and Zombies ruled the land, Russians and their Red Army alliance and Swarm fought brutal wars in zero sec to capture resources and establish bases.   It was great fun, the Dynamic politics of the eve universe always made game play fun and dangerous and profitable.

The learning curve on the other hand was brutal, just brutal.  The death penalty is ... well.. Not fun at all. But hey.. You paid your 15 bucks a month and you had complete freedom, all and everything was accessible to you. Learn all the skills you want, fly all the ships you want, do anything you want. 

I returned to the game after being away for 13 years, and here is my impression:

Tons of garbage content, new this and new that, join this faction or join that faction, you get free daily rewards just for logging in... Tons of useless, dull content added. Just like in Korean or Chinese games, anything you click on ‚Ä¶ please buy, please purchase, this token or that upgrade ‚Ä¶.. Ok whatever. 

On "Alpha" account you can't do anything, I have over 22mil in skill points, and I can't train anything, I can't get my stuff from the planet industry, I can't do this and I can't do that... basically if you are playing free... you are cannon fodder. 

OK  somehow I have 500 flex or plex or whatever that garbage is, and I can buy myself 1 month of "OMEGA" account, which is "I paid I can do anything account" or pay to win account. OK!! Great! Did that, and..... what a disappointment... Turns out I can't train any of the skills because it's either my clone is not Omega... or I have too many skill pints, so now I have to spend +$20 a month of top of +$20 for omega that I already have to train skills.... 

OKAY, that's a bummer.  But wait.. let me fly over to my planets and get resources from the manufacturing OKAY Here I come...    I see something that says... I need to purchase an additional bonus of some crap for another +$20 to be able to play planet industry.. well that sucks, okay.. let me just scan the planet for resources... NOPE cant do that because you dont have a skill remote surveying or something... but guess what I do have that skill to level 5.. and I still can't do that.... Because I need another bonus to my omega account +$20 in order to do that‚Ä¶.

Bottom line...over the years.. over many many years this game because pay to win garbage, There is ZERO of its former glory left in it.  IF you don't know any better, you might as well enjoy it .. But I remember what this game was and what it has become...  GARBAGE!

Extremely hard for the new players, all interesting things hidden under paywall, so or you need to pay subscription or grind like on full time job to get premium currency to buy subscription. Do not recommend

Quite possibly the MOST negative game I have ever played. If you're new to Eve please make sure you understand this: the whole concept of the game is to kill someone or be killed (to pod another player, or be podded), and to get the BIGGEST kill possible. The results are posted on https://zkillboard.com/ and are updated almost instantly. If you die, your deaths and all your lossed items are posted on this website. How nice is that? Eve online is a podding/killing game dressed up in a Space MMO packaging, and it fails totally to be what a true Space MMO, or real MMO is.

There is a module in this game designed so that other players can scan your ship ‚Äì view your fitting AND your cargo. What‚Äôs the aim? So they can see how valuable the kill will be (remember all kills are posted on https://zkillboard.com/). So if you have all that precious cargo, ore, or loot from a scanning trip that you want to sell, these will be scanned down at gates and will likely make you a target. So being an explorer, miner, or anything else apart from a PvP‚Äôer is just an illusion in this game.

There are NO defenses against the above scanners at all, you just have to ACCEPT it. Realistic isn‚Äôt it?

It is also not a healthy game. You are able to play the game for free and fly a good selection of ships. However, there are hundreds and hundreds of skills which need to be trained. These can be trained quickly by using real money and buying "skill injectors" (drugs?) which boost your skill level instantly, but can create a very negative spiral which causes you to drain all your cash on this game....THE RESULT? 

The result is you still LOSE EVERYTHING. Nothing is safe in this game, because of the game's objective and design, which is to trap players and FORCE them to participate in pvp (whether you like it or not - this is whether you choose to be a miner, explorer, trader, solo player or whatever). 

The travelling mechanism for instance is based on jump gates - you have to use X number of gates to get from point A to B, so if your route takes you through 7 jump gates - those are 7 opportunities for the game to force you to lose your ship, because of gate campers - well, there are the CONCORD POLICE - who are supposed to be a protective??? force for players in high-security zones, but the game developers have given them a REACTION DELAY before they come into action against an attacking player, oh how convenient!!! In low security space, there is no concord, only gate guns, which are practically useless. Oh - did I tell you? The lower security space, and null security space have the most valuable ORE to mine? So ofcourse, every player wants to go there...devisive.

The biggest trap in Eve Online is the warp disruptor or warp scrambler ‚Äì it basically stops you from being able to warp away to safety, npc‚Äôs use these too!! Once you are hit with this, there is literally nothing you can do except either try and fight, or wait for your ship to blow up. There is NO defence against this device, so once you get scrambled, that‚Äôs it! In nullsec players erect ‚Äòwarp bubbles‚Äô which stop you from warping within a huge area ‚Äì again NO DEFENCE against this! Realistic Space MMO isn‚Äôt it????

You can also be killed INSTANTLY on undocking from any high-security station, because of the REACTION DELAY of Concord, yes and I mean INSTANTLY ‚Äì you will find yourself warping without a ship.

There are two main trade hubs: Jita and Amarr. The fastest route between these systems is very short, however the game designers have intentionally placed 1 low security system on this route to increase the number of player deaths and ganking! The alternative route is nearly 50 jumps!!! This takes A VERY long time, especially if you have a big slow ship. The game then becomes a HUGE time-sink.

OH ‚Äì MINERS beware ‚Äì the biggest mining ships in the game are command ships and LOOK very appealing and mouthwatering, but now to operate them you need to use a module which stops you from moving for 5 minutes at a time ‚Äì great isn‚Äôt it? Means you can‚Äôt warp away if you see an enemy nearby, or to even prepare yourself to move your ASSETS to a safe spot, again you are FORCED into a combat situation YOU DIDN‚ÄôT ASK FOR. AND ‚Äì these mining ships are unable to use weapons!!!! SO YOU CAN‚ÄôT DEFEND YOURSELF. Yes you can use drones‚Ä¶.but what good are 5 drones against more than 1 player, especially when drones can be killed!!!???

Want to be a hauler (trucker)? Good luck! The hauling missions are designed so that you earn just a tiny amount of in-game currency for each mission, which basically makes it a waste of time, so nobody does it. Now there‚Äôs a ‚Äúcourier contracts‚Äù market which is where players create missions for you to haul items from A to B for a much better fee, but ofcourse there‚Äôs a catch to this: to accept the contract you usually have to pay down a ‚Äúcollateral‚Äù worth between 500 million and several billion ‚Äì yes, that much!!! WHY?? So that when your ship gets scanned, then destroyed (and it will), you'll not only lose the items you‚Äôre hauling AND your ship, but the collateral you paid as well!!! GREAT DESIGN!

The game is designed around gang warfare, or a large number of players, versus just 1. So if you want to be a solo miner, with a dream of owning your own station and miniature empire, and protecting yourself using great ships and weapons against attacking players, FORGET IT!! IT IS NOT POSSIBLE. All ships are designed for GROUP engagements, and stations themselves are so poor at offense, a single player can easily evade their weapons, it‚Äôs actually a complete joke just watching them in action. (Oh ‚Äì stations take 24 hours to anchor in space, and during a certain timeframe they can be stolen!!!) So solo players with stations ALWAYS get wardecced (basically get their stations destroyed) eventually by other corporations. THERE ARE NO OPTIONS TO DEFEND YOURSELF unless you have other players to help you (LOTS) , even though you spent ALL THAT MONEY and time setting up your business empire. 

If you want to be a miner, you will die, if you want to have your own solo station/empire, it will all be destroyed, if you want to roam null sec seeing what's around, you will die, if you want to do high-sec missions you will die ‚Äì of boredom, if you want to boost your skills and level up your character using an omega subscription, and fly EXPENSIVE, VERY GOOD LOOKING ships - these will all be destroyed, because THAT IS THE PLOT OF THE GAME. NOTHING HAS ANY VALUE.

Even the PvE gameplay forces you into situations where you get destroyed - oh  and there are spreadsheets, and all that crap you can read online about which enemies do which damage types and what weapons you need in certain zones to be fitted to your ship, but the game will eventually win, you will get attacked by a random npc who is 50x stronger than you and be unable to warp away and have to sit and watch your beautiful ship get destroyed slowly. AND THERE IS NOTHING YOU CAN DO!!! Quite sickening.

The only true space MMO feature this game has ....oh wait??? I can't think of one. Oh - maybe the player market - where you buy modules to fit your ship with, so it can get destroyed.

Think about it like this: Eve online is a game where you can pay ¬£5,000 of real money on the item called PLEX - sell all these PLEX at the main trading station in game, and then convert it to in-game currency, then use it buy the most expensive items in the game - you load these items into a tiny frigate, undock your ship, wait for it to get scanned by another player, or just warp to any gate, and watch it get blown up.

OR - you can just undock, right-click your vessel and choose "auto-destruct".

OR - you can stay docked, right-click on the expensive stuff you bought, and click "trash". Nice game - WHERE EVERYTHING IS DESTROYABLE!!

To sum it all up: Eve Online = a game where you play to be destroyed, and pay to be destroyed.

EVE is more interesting to read about than to actually play.
Power bloc clashes and battles involving thousands of pilots sound epic. I came to the game for the beautiful ships and space scenery, expecting an incredible adventure. But all the magic fades away right after completing the tutorial missions.

For decades, EVE has suffered from long-standing issues that seriously affect the player base. The support is unfriendly, and there‚Äôs no meaningful mid-game content. The core game design combines two incompatible things: grind and roaming. Whether you want PvE or PvP, you often have to roam endlessly. In the end, you spend far more hours searching and waiting than actually playing. The loot is inconsistent, and it‚Äôs easy to waste several hours grinding for a trivial reward.

The game gives massive PvP advantages to older accounts. Veterans know a thousand ways to destroy a new player. Newcomers in weak ships are killed ‚Äúfor fun‚Äù by pilots flying T2 or T3 ships through multiple accounts. They brag about their kill counts. It quickly becomes clear that new players are just prey ‚Äî farmed by veterans. At that point, you realize what the developers‚Äô design truly is, and it‚Äôs easy to decide your time deserves a better experience elsewhere.

The dev team completely lacks the courage to evolve the game. Everything is built around keeping EVE frozen in its broken state while a small core of loyal players keeps paying. Even multiboxing has been integrated into the monetization system.

Imagine looking for fair, exciting PvP ‚Äî and your opponent simply switches to a second window with a stronger ship to finish you off once his first one tackles you. Where‚Äôs the fun in that? Gang-style PvP offers no thrill ‚Äî only wasted time and a lost ship.

Large-scale battles with thousands of pilots cause massive time dilation. Ships pile up, and the server runs at the speed of 2 FPS per minute ‚Äî pure disappointment.

CCP keeps developing new games instead of fixing EVE. Yet all it would take to revive EVE is the courage to address its core problems.

Do not play this game unless you are willing to spend hundreds of dollars of your own money to be able to particpate.  Just signing up for omega won't get you anywhere, you will be hunted down by players who have years and thousands of dollars invested in this game.  You do have the option of catching up, so to speak, but that would require you to buy Skill Points which range anywhere from 10 dollars for a small amount upwards of 500 dollars.  

The game is designed to extract as much money from the player in order to participate, this is just the facts of the game.  You need time to train skills, but you only learn skills slightly faster if you pay for omega.  You then will acquire the skills to fly ships that don't get 2 shot by level 1 PVE mobs or 1 shot with the majority of players who have years (and thousands of dollars) invested into this game.  

You can get by doing High Sec PVE or Mining, but you're making virtually no money for hours worth of work, but if you get ganked you've basically lost a ship and several hours worth of money to recover that ship and if you are a casual player it will take you several hours or maybe days depending  on your time spent to recover your losses.  

That's where the credit card comes in, you're going to die non-stop, you will get griefed by players and they will mass report you if you retaliate for being picked on or camped so don't say anything to them, just accept it.  You can recover your losses which you will face a metric ton of losses, but the easiest way to earn isk is to spend 5-10 dollars every day so you can participate in the game.

Scamming is promoted in this game, you will have corps who will take advantage of you, you will have PVP corps who will see the new player flying around your brand new ship which cost you a lot of time and effort to buy, or your own hard earned dollars and they will camp you.  From there they will either hold you in space so you can't move, tell you to give them all of your money and they will destroy your ship.  You will then start off with nothing and have to spend weeks recovering all of the funds you lost.  If you don't give them your money they will blow up your ship, if they are kind they won't blow up your ship after you give away all of your money but that's pretty rare.

On the positive side, EVE Online has one of the most impressive player-driven economies and large-scale battles ever seen in gaming. But all that potential is buried under layers of outdated design and user hostility.

It‚Äôs a game that could have been a living universe ‚Äî but instead, it feels like a sterile simulation that forgot about fun somewhere along the way.

At least in Elite Dangerous you can enjoy the game without having to deal with non-consensual PVP, ingame scammers, market scalpers, a heavy alt account focused culture, and recruiters that don't care about leaving people alone. Not to mention 95% of the ships and skills are locked behind the subscription service.

That not enough to be a red flag? Thinking of joining EVE's equivalent of a guild or an alliance? That is, in my opinion, probably one of the worst decisions you can make. While I am sure there are some good groups out there that are playing just for fun, there are ones out there that will dictate how and when you play. How often you have to be on to stay in their group and what skills you are going to train. Alliances such as "The Initiative" and "Brave" are two of the older groups, from my understanding, and will make such dictates. Both also are lead by vainglorious, narcissistic leaders who only care about their appearance and how many people they can get to show up for activities they decide are important. Additionally, 99% of these player groups in EVE online will put pressure on their players to make additional subscription accounts to bolster their numbers rather then trying to bring in new players. 

If you are looking to spend too many hours in-game only to be rewarded less then an Amazon fulfillment center employee, then be my guest and give Eve online a download. Just don't complain that you were not warned.

Unless you plan on buying, WITH REAL MONEY, multiple accounts worth of Omega time (which is this game's subscription), then don't bother. Everyone does what is called "multiboxing", which in most games is heavily against TOS because it gives a massive unfair advantage to people with mountains of cash to burn. Multiboxing is the act of having multiple accounts playing at once. Here's the issue: This game's devs ENCOURAGE multiboxing. They encourage something that actively makes the game worse for people who don't have tons of monthly cash to burn. There is a system specifically meant to make multiboxing easier/better, and that is allowing you to multibox other characters on the same account, but ONLY if they are also Omega. 

I'm sure the devs will try to comment here to defend this stupid "medhanic", but if not just know they 100% encourage this, and if you don't multibox, you will be essentially barred from half of the game's content because of it. 
Want to just enjoy one character? Too bad, spend 100s of bucks a month bucko.
